greetingFacts.haw-aloha: Used in Hawaii for hello, goodbye, and warmth in everyday life.
greetingFacts.kor-annyeong: A polite Korean greeting used in most daily situations.
greetingFacts.jpn-konnichiwa: A standard daytime Japanese greeting with a friendly tone.
greetingFacts.tha-sawasdee: Thai greeting used throughout the day, often paired with a wai; speakers add polite endings by their own gender (khrap for men, kha for women).
greetingFacts.hin-namaste: A respectful greeting in India often used in formal and informal settings.
greetingFacts.spa-hola: A simple Spanish greeting used in almost any social context.
greetingFacts.deu-guten-tag: A formal German greeting used in daytime conversations.
greetingFacts.fra-bonjour: A common French daytime greeting used in both casual and formal settings.
greetingFacts.ita-ciao: Italian greeting used casually for hello and goodbye.
greetingFacts.ara-marhaba: A warm Arabic greeting broadly understood across regions.
greetingFacts.deu-moin: Classic in Northern Germany at any hour; locals joke that “Moin Moin” is mostly said by tourists.
greetingFacts.gsw-gruezi: A polite Swiss German hello often heard in shops, trains, and mountain towns.
greetingFacts.eus-kaixo: Basque greeting used in Euskadi; hearing it is a quick sign the region keeps its language alive.
greetingFacts.gle-dia-dhuit: Irish for “hello,” literally “God be with you,” and still common in Gaeltacht areas.
greetingFacts.cym-shwmae: Friendly Welsh hello that often appears on bilingual signs and local radio intros.
greetingFacts.isl-godan-daginn: Icelandic “good day”; locals often shorten it in casual speech, especially in Reykjavík cafés.
greetingFacts.ces-ahoj: Popular Czech hello among friends; it began as a sailors’ call and stuck in daily speech.
greetingFacts.swe-hej: Default Swedish hello for both friends and coworkers, often doubled in cheerful “hej hej.”
greetingFacts.nld-hoi: Casual Dutch greeting common in the Netherlands and Flanders, especially among younger speakers.
greetingFacts.mri-kia-ora: Māori greeting in New Zealand used for hello, thanks, and general positive energy.
greetingFacts.khm-suostei: Khmer greeting heard across Cambodia; respectful tone matters as much as the words.
greetingFacts.lao-sabaidee: Lao greeting also tied to well-being, reflecting a calm and friendly social style.
greetingFacts.swa-jambo: Widely recognized Swahili greeting in East Africa; many locals also use “Hujambo?” for “How are you?”
greetingFacts.yue-nei-hou: Cantonese greeting common in Hong Kong; tones matter, so pronunciation changes meaning fast.
greetingFacts.zho-ni-hao: Mandarin greeting used across China; in casual chats people may jump straight to daily-life questions.
greetingFacts.fallback: A universal greeting to kick off your next trip idea.

settings.defaultVisibilityToggleDescription: Choose whether new trips are public on your profile by default.

stamps.empty: No stamps match this filter yet.
